intro: Cardamine violifolia var. pilosa, commonly known as hairy liverworts, is a species of moss-like plant belonging to the family Ptygnathaceae. It is characterized by its small, delicate leaves that are covered in fine, hairy structures, giving it a distinctive appearance. This plant typically grows in moist, shaded environments such as forest floors or rocky crevices. It has a simple structure with no true roots, stems, or leaves in the traditional sense, instead relying on rhizoids for anchorage. The plant plays a role in soil stabilization and provides habitat for microorganisms in its native ecosystems.
